case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax v. M/s Jaipuria China Clay Mines P. Ltd.

facts.text: Appeal numbered C. A. No. 307 of 1964 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION C. A. No. 307 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal from Judgement and Order dated 6th February 1962 of Calcutta High Court in Income Tax Reference No. 72 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the, Judgement and Order dated 6th February 1962 of the Calcutta High Court in Income Tax Reference No. 72 of 1957.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Sikri, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Sikri, J.

facts.text: Appeal by certificate granted by High Court of Calcutta against its judgment in reference under s. 66 of Indian Income Tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by certificate granted by the High Court of Calcutta against its judgment in a reference made to it under s. 66 of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922  hereinafter re- 4 5 0 ferred to as the Act.

facts.text: Question referred by Appellate Tribunal at instance of assessee: Whether unabsorbed depreciation of past years should be added to current year depreciation and aggregate deducted from total income for 1952-53.

anchor.surface_text: The question referred to it by the Appellate Tribunal, at the instance of the assessee, was as follows Whether in the facts and circumstances of the case, the unabsorbed depreciation of the past years should be added to the depreciation of the current year and the aggregate of the unabsorbed depreciation and the current years depreciation be deducted from the total income of the previous year relevant for the assessment year 1952-53.

facts.text: Assessee is M/s Jaipuria China Clay Mines P. Ltd., Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: The Income Tax Officer assessing the respondent, M s Jaipuria China Clay Mines  P  Ltd. Calcutta, hereinafter referred to as the assessee,

facts.text: Income Tax Officer assessed assessee for year 1952-53.

anchor.surface_text: The Income Tax Officer assessing the respondent, M s Jaipuria China Clay Mines  P  Ltd. Calcutta, hereinafter referred to as the assessee, for the year1952-53

facts.text: ITO computed total income at Rs. 14,041/- before charging depreciation for 1952-53.

anchor.surface_text: companyputed its total income at Rs. 14,041/- before charging depreciation for that year.

facts.text: ITO deducted depreciation for the year amounting to Rs. 5,360/-, computing profit of Rs. 8,681/-.

anchor.surface_text: From that figure he deducted depreciation for the year amounting to Rs. 5,360/-, thus companyputing a profit of Rs. 8,681/-.

facts.text: ITO deducted Rs. 8,681/- in respect of losses during 1947-48, working out business income as nil.

anchor.surface_text: From this figure he deducted an equivalent amount, i.e., Rs. 8,681/-, in respect of losses during 1947- 48, and he thus worked out the business income as nil.

facts.text: ITO computed dividend income at Rs. 2,01,130/- and determined total income at this figure.

anchor.surface_text: He then companyputed the dividend income at Rs. 2,01,130/- and determined the total income at this figure and levied tax on it.

facts.text: Assessee had unabsorbed depreciation aggregating to Rs. 76,857/- from past years.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee had in its favour an unabsorbed depreciation aggregating to Rs. 76,857/-,

facts.text: Assessee contended before ITO that unabsorbed depreciation Rs. 76,857/- should be deducted from dividend income, reducing total income to Rs. 1,32,955/-.

anchor.surface_text: and it companytended before the Income Tax Officer that this sum should be deducted from The income received from dividends, which, if done, would reduce the total income to Rs. 1,32,955/-, but the Income Tax Officer refused to accede to this companytention.

facts.text: Income Tax Officer refused assessee's contention on unabsorbed depreciation.

anchor.surface_text: but the Income Tax Officer refused to accede to this companytention.

facts.text: Appellant Assistant Commissioner upheld order of Income Tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellant Assistant Commissioner upheld the order of the Income Tax Officer

facts.text: Assessee's appeal to Appellate Tribunal was dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: and the assessees appeal to the Appellate Tribunal met with the same fate.

facts.text: High Court accepted contention of assessee and answered question in favour of assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, however, accepted the companytention of the assessee and answered the question referred, to it in favour of the assessee.

facts.text: Supreme Court concerned with law as it stood on April 1, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: We are companycerned with the law as it stood on April 1, 1952.

facts.text: Supreme Court agrees with High Court that question should be answered in favour of assessee.

anchor.surface_text: In companyclusion, we agree with the High Court that the question -referred to it should be answered in favour of the assessee.

facts.text: Words inserted in proviso b to s.10(2)(vi) by s.8 of Indian Income Tax Amendment Act, 1953 (25 of 1953) with effect from April 1, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Proviso  b  to S. 10 2   vi . On this a great deal of argument has been addressed to us and it reads as follows  b  where, in the assessment of the assessee or if the assessee is a registered firm, in the assessment of its partners, full effect cannot be given to any such allowance in any year number being a year which ended prior to the last day of April, 1939, owing to there being numberprofits or gains chargeable for that year, or owing to the profits or gains chargeable being less than the allowance, then, subject to the provisions of clause  b  of the proviso to sub-section  2  of section 24, the allowance or part of the allowance to which effect has number been given, as the case, may be, shall be added to the amount of the allow- ance for depreciation for the following year and deemed to be part of that allowance, or if there is numbersuch allowance for that year, he deemed to be the allowance for that year, and so on for succeeding years

concepts.interpretation: Provides for set off of losses from one head against income from other heads in the same year, and carry forward of business losses for up to six years against same business profits; proviso gives priority to such losses over depreciation carry forwards.

concepts.unlisted_description: Set off and carry forward of losses

anchor.surface_text: 24 1  Where any assessee sustains a loss of profits or gains in any year under any of the heads mentioned in section 6, he shall be entitled to have the amount of the loss set off against his income, profits or gains under any other head in that year Provided that Provided further that when the assessee is an unregistered firm which has number been assessed under the provisions of clause  b  of sub- section  5  of section 23, in the manner applicable to a registered firm, any,such loss shall be set off only against the income, profits and gains of the firm and number against the income, profits and gains of any of the partners of the firm and where the assessee is a registered firm, any loss which cannot be set off against other income, profits and gains of the firm shall be apportioned between the partners of the firm and they 45 2 alone shall be entitled to have the amount of the loss set off under this section.

concepts.interpretation: Allows set off of business loss against other heads like dividends in the same year.

anchor.surface_text: Where any assessee sustains loss of profits or gains in any year, being a previous year number earlier than the previous year for the assessment for the year ending on the 31st day of March, 1940, in any business, profes- sion or vocation and the loss cannot be wholly set off under sub-section  1 , so much of the loss as is number so set off or the whole loss where the assessee had numberother head of income, shall be carried forward to the following year and set off against the profits and gains, if any, of the assessee from the same business, profession or vocation for that year and if it cannot be wholly so set ,off, the amount of loss number so set off shall be carried forward to the following year, and so on but numberloss shall be so carried forward for more than six years

concepts.interpretation: Carry forward of unabsorbed business losses only against same business profits for limited years; does not include depreciation losses which are handled under s.10(2)(vi).

anchor.surface_text: the scheme of the Act is that the tax is levied in respect of the total income of the previous year of every individual, Hindu Undivided family, etc., and the total income companysists of income under various heads such as Salaries, Interest on Securities, Income from Property, Profits and gains of business, profession or vocation, and Income from other sources and Capital gains.

concepts.interpretation: Total income is aggregate after pooling income/loss from all heads, with allowances like depreciation deducted; unfair to compute without set off across heads.

arguments.claim: Unabsorbed depreciation aggregating Rs. 76,857/- from past years should be deducted from dividend income, reducing total income to Rs. 1,32,955/-

anchor.surface_text: The assessee had in its favour an unabsorbed depreciation aggregating to Rs. 76,857/-, and it contended before the Income Tax Officer that this sum should be deducted from The income received from dividends, which, if done, would reduce the total income to Rs. 1,32,955/-, but the

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ing been provided in s. 10 2  vi  and in a different manner s. 24 2  only deals with losses other than the losses due to depreciation. In companyclusi

arguments.court_reasoning: Court interprets ss. 6, 10, 24 and proviso b to s.10(2)(vi) to allow set off of carried forward depreciation against other heads in total income computation

arguments.claim: Depreciation allowance compensates capital loss, is a charge only on business profits, and deficiency from unabsorbed depreciation is not a 'loss of profits and gains' under s.24(1) that can be set off against other heads like dividends

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sastri, learned counsel for the revenue, urges that depreciation, although a permissible allowance under s. 10 2  of the Act, serves to compensate an assessee for the capital loss suffered by him by way of depreciation of his assets. He says that if it bad number been expressly allowed as allowance, it would have been treated as capital expenditure and would have been excluded. He further says that depreciation is a charge on the profits of a business.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ances mentioned in s. 10 2 . They all have to be deducted from the gross profits and gains of a business. According to companymercial principles, depr

arguments.court_reasoning: Depreciation treated as allowance under s.10(2)(vi) like others, not distinguished; carried forward under proviso b and set off in total income pooling across heads

arguments.claim: Act requires assessment of total income by pooling income/loss from all heads; no distinction between s.10(2) allowances including depreciation which creates loss if unabsorbed, allowing set off against other heads per commercial principles and legislative history

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Rajgopala Sastri for the assessee relies on the history of the legislation and a number of authorities to support the judgment of the High Court. Apart from authority, looking at the Act as it stood on April 1, 1952, it is clear that the underlying idea of the Act is to assess the total income of an assessee. Prima facie, it would be unfair to compute the total income of an assessee carrying on business without pooling the income from business with the income or loss under other heads.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e business whose income is being companyputed under S.10. It appears that the Legislature accepted the interpretation placed by various High Courts on

arguments.court_reasoning: Court adopts and expands this view through textual analysis and precedents

arguments.claim: Phrase 'in the assessment of the assessee or ... partners, full effect cannot be given to any such allowance' in proviso b to s.10(2)(vi) refers to total income assessment where depreciation is set off against other heads

anchor.surface_text: Bearing these two considerations in mind, if one looks at the language of proviso b to S. 10 2 vi the first question that arises is What is the meaning of the expression in the assessment of the assessee or if the assessee is a registered firm, in the assessment of the partners, full effect cannot be given to any such allowance in any year ? It would be noted that the words used are in the assessment of the assessee or the assessment of the partners.

arguments.claim: Revenue's interpretation that proviso b contemplates set off only against other business of partners is unsound, as it fails where some partners have no other business

anchor.surface_text: Taking the case of the partners of a registered firm, the assessment must be their individual assessments, i.e. assessments in which the profits from the firm and other sources are pooled together. The Legislature is clearly assuming that effect can be given to depreciation allowance in the assessment of a partner the only way effect can be given in the assessment of a partner is by setting 4 54 it off against income, profits and gains under other heads.

arguments.claim: 'No profits or gains chargeable for that year' in proviso b not confined to business profits under s.10 but includes across heads in total income

anchor.surface_text: Now, if this is the inference to be drawn from these words, it is quite clear that the words no profits or gains chargeable for that year are not confined. to profits and gains derived from the business whose income is being computed under S.10.

arguments.claim: Precedents from Lahore HC, Madras HC (Suppan), Nagpur JC, East Punjab HC, Bombay HC (Ambika) support set off of unabsorbed depreciation against other heads, with s.24(2)(b) proviso giving priority only to business losses over depreciation

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the Legislature accepted the interpretation placed by various High Courts on the Act as it stood before it was amended by Act 25 of 1953. In 1930, the Lahore High Court in Messrs Karam Ilahi Muhammad Shafi v. The Commissioner of Income Tax, Delhi 1  held that depreciation on buildings and machinery can be set off against gains and profits accrued to the owner of those buildings and machinery from other sources such as rental from house property during the year in question-.

arguments.claim: Post-1953 amendment cases from Bombay HC (Ravi Industries) and Gujarat HC continue to allow set off of carried forward depreciation against other income

anchor.surface_text: After the amendment, the same view has been taken in Commissioner of Income-Tax, Bombay City v. Ravi Industries Ltd.  2  by the Bombay High Court, and in Commissioner of Income-Tax J. Girdharilal Harivallabhadas Mills Co. Ltd.  3  by the Gujarat Hgh Court.

arguments.claim: Madras HC in B. Nagi Reddy wrongly holds depreciation only chargeable to business profits without creating set-off loss, making carry forward redundant; rejected as it misreads s.10(2)(vi) proviso b and ignores distinction from s.24 losses

anchor.surface_text: The only contrary view which has been placed before is is that of the Madras High Court in Commissioner of Incomeax Madras v. B. Nagi Reddy  4   , but we are unable to agree with he view expressed in the last case. The Madras High Court observed at p. 196 as follows In our opinion, the statute leads one to the irresistible conclusion that the depreciation allowance must be a charge only on the profits.

holdings.text: In conclusion, we agree with the High Court that the question referred to it should be answered in favour of the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: In conclusion, we agree with the High Court that the question -referred to it should be answered in favour of the assessee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court interprets proviso (b) to s.10(2)(vi) to permit adding unabsorbed depreciation to current depreciation for deduction from total income after set-off of business losses; distinguishes from s.24 losses; follows multiple High Court precedents.

holdings.text: the assessment must be their individual assessments, i.e. assessments in which the profits from the firm and other sources are pooled together. The Legislature is clearly assuming that effect can be given to depreciation allowance in the assessment of a partner the only way effect can be given in the assessment of a partner is by setting it off against income, profits and gains under other heads.

anchor.surface_text: Taking the case of the partners of a registered firm, the assessment must be their individual assessments, i.e. assessments in which the profits from the firm and other sources are pooled together. The Legislature is clearly assuming that effect can be given to depreciation allowance in the assessment of a partner the only way effect can be given in the assessment of a partner is by setting 4 54 it off against income, profits and gains under other heads.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of 'in the assessment of the assessee or...partners' refers to total income computation pooling all heads; Revenue's limit to partners' other business rejected as incomplete.

holdings.text: the words no profits or gains chargeable for that year are not confined to profits and gains derived from the business whose income is being computed under S.10.

anchor.surface_text: Now, if this is the inference to be drawn from these words, it is quite clear that the words no profits or gains chargeable for that year are not confined. to profits and gains derived from the business whose income is being computed under S.10.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Flows from interpretation of 'assessment of assessee'; extends to total income across heads under scheme of ss.6,10.

holdings.text: we are unable to agree with the view expressed in the last case [Commissioner of Income Tax Madras v. B. Nagi Reddy].

anchor.surface_text: The only contrary view which has been placed before is is that of the Madras High Court in Commissioner of Incomeax Madras v. B. Nagi Reddy  4   , but we are unable to agree with he view expressed in the last case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects Madras HC view that depreciation only charges business profits without creating set-off loss; explains proviso b s.10(2)(vi) not redundant as distinct from s.24 losses with different carry-forward rules.

holdings.text: s. 24 2  only deals with losses other than the losses due to depreciation. This carry forward having been provided in s. 10 2  vi  and in a different manner.

anchor.surface_text: But it is wrong to assume that s. 24 2  also deals with the carrying forward of depreciation. This carry forward having been provided in s. 10 2  vi  and in a different manner s. 24 2  only deals with losses other than the losses due to depreciation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Depreciation carry-forward under s.10(2)(vi)b indefinite and against any profits; business losses under s.24(2) limited to 6 years and same business; proviso s.24(2)b prioritises losses.

precedents.cited_proposition: depreciation on buildings and machinery can be set off against gains and profits accrued to the owner of those buildings and machinery from other sources such as rental from house property during the year in question

precedents.case_name: A Suppan Chettiar Co. v. The Commissioner of Income-Tax, Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: where the profits and gains of a business are insufficient to cover the full depreciation allowance under section 10(2)(vi) of the Income-tax Act on the machinery, plant, etc., used for the purposes of that business, the excess depreciation can be set off against the profits and gains of other business or from other sources

anchor.surface_text: 4 Income Tax Cases 255 A.I.R. 1930 Nag.

precedents.case_name: Ballarpur Collieries v. The Commissioner of Income Tar, Central Provinces
precedents.cited_proposition: the partners of the assessee, a registered firm owning collieries, were entitled to set off depreciation against the other income of the members of the firm under s. 24 of the Income Tax Act

precedents.case_name: Laxmichand Jaipuria Spinning and Weaving Mills, In re
precedents.cited_proposition: arrived at the same conclusion. The High Court further held that the object of proviso (b) to sub-section (2) of section 24 is only to give preference to ordinary losses incurred by an assessee in regard to set-off over the loss which comes under clause (b) of the proviso to sub-section (2)(vi) of section 10

precedents.case_name: Ambika Silk Mills Co. Ltd. v Commissioner of Income- Tax
precedents.cited_proposition: understood the effect of proviso b to s. 10(2)(vi) and proviso b to s. 24(2) as follows If a business was worked at a loss in any particular year, the loss can be set off against any other head under section 24(1) if the loss cannot be fully set off then it can be only set off against the profits of that particular business ... But in the case of depreciation ... there would be no limit to the carrying forward of that depreciation

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-Tax, Bombay City v. Ravi Industries Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: the same view has been taken

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-Tax J. Girdharilal Harivallabhadas Mills Co. Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: the same view has been taken

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Incomeax Madras v. B. Nagi Reddy
precedents.cited_proposition: the depreciation allowance must be a charge only on the profits. The limit of the charge is the limit of the profits. The non-existence of profits will prevent the absorption of the allowance. There is no warrant for taking in and absorbing the depreciation allowance in the profit and loss account to work out a loss

anchor.surface_text: Taking the case of the partners of a registered firm, the assessment must be their individual assessments, i.e. assessments in which the profits from the firm and other sources are pooled together. The Legislature is clearly assuming that effect can be given to depreciation allowance in the assessment of a partner the only way effect can be given in the assessment of a partner is by setting 4 54 it off against income, profits and gains under other heads.

But it is wrong to assume that s. 24 2  also deals with the carrying forward of depreciation. This carry forward having been provided in s. 10 2  vi  and in a different manner s. 24 2  only deals with losses other than the losses due to depreciation.
